quizName: 3. The rights of the data subject
introText: You can use this test to assess your company's compliance with the obligations of a controller. After submitting your answers, you will receive a report with compiled feedback on your answers and recommended measures based on them.

questions.question: How can a data subject approach your company in order to exercise their rights, such as checking their personal data or requesting its erasure?

choices.option: We have contact details and instructions for this on our website
choices.selectedText: The company must ensure that data subjects can exercise their data protection rights easily. Data subjects must be informed of how they can exercise their rights. In addition, the company's contact details must be easily available. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/rights-of-the-data-subject

questions.guideText:
According to the General Data Protection Regulation, data subjects have the right

  • to obtain information on the processing of their personal data;
  • of access to their data;
  • to rectification of their data;
  • to the erasure of their data and to be forgotten;
  • to restrict the processing of their data;
  • to data portability;
  • to object to the processing of their data; and
  • not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing.

The company must ensure that data subjects can exercise their data protection rights easily. Data subjects must be informed of how they can exercise their rights. In addition, the company's contact details must be easily available. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/rights-of-the-data-subject

questions.question: What do you do if your company receives a request regarding the rights of the data subject?

choices.option: We have clear guidelines for processing the request within the time period required by the General Data Protection Regulation
choices.selectedText: The controller is required to ensure that the rights of the data subject are realised within the time limits specified in the GDPR. As a rule, data subjects must receive a response without undue delay and at the latest within one month of receipt of the request. You should have instructions in place for realising the rights of the data subject so that you are able to realise them as required by the GDPR. The company must specify the person responsible for processing requests, as well as how they should be processed. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/right-of-access.
choices.selectedActions: Great! Finally, ensure that you have gone over the instructions with your personnel.

questions.question: How have you ensured that the identity of a person requesting to exercise the rights of the data subject is verified before the request is carried out?

choices.option: We have a clear procedure in place for verifying the identity of the data subject
choices.selectedText: The GDPR does not contain any provisions on how the identity of the data subject should be verified. Appropriate procedures are already available in many places. For example, the controller may have verified the data subject's identity before concluding an agreement with them or obtaining their consent for the processing. In such cases, this personal data can also be used to verify the identity of the data subject in connection with exercising the rights of the data subject. If you have verified the identity of the data subject by email, for example, email identification can also be sufficient for carrying out the data subject's request. You may not collect more data on the data subject for identification purposes than the company is already processing. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/right-of-access
choices.selectedActions: Great! Make sure that you are not collecting more data on the data subject for identification purposes than the company is already processing (e.g. requiring the data subject to present identification can often lead to the company collecting more data than it previously held). The controller must facilitate the exercise of the rights of the data subject (e.g. visiting the controller's office cannot be the only way to verify identity)

questions.question: What do you do if a data subject wants access to their personal data being held by the company and a copy of the data?

choices.option: We have a clear procedure in place for supplying the copy and other information
choices.selectedText: You need to have instructions in place for realising the rights of the data subject to be able to grant data subjects access to their data as required by the GDPR. The company should consider questions such as whether the right applies to all personal data being assessed, and how the right (including the delivery of a copy) will be realised in practice. You should also consider whether you could offer data subjects a way to exercise their rights through an electronic service. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/right-of-access
choices.selectedActions: Great! You can also consider whether you could offer data subjects a way to access their data and obtain copies of it through an electronic service.

questions.guideText: Data subjects have the right to receive confirmation from the controller whether your company is processing personal data concerning them. If the data subject's personal data is being processed, the controller is required to supply a copy of the processed personal data to the data subject. In addition to the copy, you must provide the data subject with other information related to the processing, such as the purposes of the processing and the recipients and storage times of the data. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/right-of-access

questions.question: What will you do if a data subject requests the erasure of their data from your company´s data files and databases?

choices.option: We have a clear procedure in place for the erasure of data
choices.selectedText: You must draw up instructions for realising the right of erasure / right to be forgotten in order to be able to implement it as required by the GDPR. Your company must consider questions such as whether the erasure of data applies to the personal data being assessed, whether there are any obstacles to erasure (e.g. statutory storage periods), and how the erasure will be implemented in practice. You should also consider whether you could offer data subjects the opportunity to erase their data through an electronic service. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/right-to-erasure
choices.selectedActions: Great! You can also consider whether you could offer data subjects the opportunity to erase their data through an electronic service.

You should also consider whether you could offer data subjects the opportunity to erase their data through an electronic service. Read more: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/right-to-erasure
choices.selectedActions: Prepare and draw up instructions for the eventuality that a data subject requests the erasure of their data. Check whether there are any obstacles to erasing data (e.g. statutory storage periods) and plan how the erasure will be implemented in practice. You can also consider whether you could offer data subjects the opportunity to erase their data through an electronic service.

questions.guideText: The data subjects right to have their data erased is also called the right to be forgotten. A data subject has the right to have their data erased in cases such as when the data is no longer necessary for the purposes for which it was originally collected. Having your data erased is not always possible, for example if the data must be stored to comply with a statutory obligation. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/right-to-erasure

questions.question: What will you do if a data subject wants to restrict the processing of their personal data by your company?

choices.option: We have a clear procedure in place for restriction requests
choices.selectedText: You must draw up instructions for realising the right to restriction of processing in order to be able to implement the right as required by the GDPR. Your company should consider questions such as how the processing will be implemented in practice at the information system level, and on what basis could your company possibly refuse requests for the restriction of processing. Processing can be restricted by means such as transferring select data to another processing system, preventing users from accessing the data, or erasing published data from a website. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/right-to-restriction-of-processing
choices.selectedActions: Great! Make sure that the data subject is informed before the restriction of processing is lifted.

questions.question: What will you do if a data subject wants to exercise their right to object to the processing of personal data?

choices.option: We have a clear procedure in place for situations in which a data subject objects to the processing of their data
choices.selectedText: You need to draw up instructions for realising the right to object to processing in order to be able to implement the right as required by the GDPR. Among other things, the company should consider how the right to object applies to the processing being assessed, and how the right to object will be implemented in practice. If the right to object is exercised in relation to processing for the purposes of direct marketing, the controller may not refuse the request. In other words, the controller has no room for discretion in carrying out the request. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/right-to-object

questions.guideText:
In certain situations, the data subject has the right to object to the processing of their personal data, that is, request the controller not to process it at all. In such cases, the processing must be stopped, unless

  • the controller is able to demonstrate compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the data subject; or
  • the processing is necessary for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims.

More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/right-to-object

questions.question: Does the processing of personal data by your company include automated decision-making that produces legal effects concerning the data subject or has a similar significant effect on them?

choices.option: Yes
choices.selectedText: As a rule, the controller may not make decisions concerning the data subject based solely on automated processing, such as profiling, and which produce legal effects concerning the data subject or have similar significant effects on them (such as loan or recruitment decisions made automatically without any human contribution). Automated decision-making is permitted in certain exceptional cases, however. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/automated-decision-making-and-profiling
choices.selectedActions: Read the instructions concerning automated decision-making. Determine whether you are making automated decisions and whether one of the exceptional grounds provided for in the GDPR applies to that processing. Make sure that appropriate safeguards are implemented in relation to the processing.

choices.option: Yes
choices.selectedText:
If automated decisions are being made, the company must

  • inform the data subjects of the automated decision-making;
  • offer the data subjects simple methods for demanding human involvement in the processing, expressing their point of view and challenging the decision; and
  • check the algorithms and processed data regularly in order to ensure that the decision-making process is functioning as intended and not leading to, for example, discriminatory processing.

The company must specify how the safeguards, such as human involvement and algorithm-checking, are implemented in practice.
